semantic_title: Non-Integral Signs and Symptoms Should Be Coded When Present
section_path: Section I > B. General Coding Guidelines > 6. Conditions that are not an integral part of a disease process

content.full_text: Additional signs and symptoms that may not be associated routinely with a disease process should be coded when present. (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
content.summary: Requires coding of signs and symptoms that are not routinely associated with the primary disease process when they are present. (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
key_concepts: Non-integral symptoms should be coded additionally (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
Not routinely associated with disease process (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
Must be present to be coded (Evidence: pg no: 13, L46)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code additional signs/symptoms not routinely associated with disease process (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a patient presents with signs or symptoms that are not typically expected or routinely associated with their primary disease process, these should be coded as additional diagnoses to provide a complete picture of the patient's condition (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)

workflow_steps: Step 3: Determine which symptoms are NOT routinely associated with the primary disease
Step 4: Code the primary disease plus non-integral symptoms
Step 5: Sequence according to encounter circumstances

references_to.title: Conditions that are an integral part of a disease process
references_to.explanation: Contrasts with integral conditions that should not be coded separately

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with pneumonia also presents with severe headache
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Final diagnosis: Community-acquired pneumonia. Patient also complaining of severe headache, unrelated to respiratory condition.
step_by_step: Step 3: Determine headache is not routinely associated with pneumonia
Step 4: Code both pneumonia and headache
Step 5: Sequence pneumonia first as primary condition

correct_coding.sequencing: Primary condition first, then non-integral symptom
correct_coding.rationale: Headache is not routinely associated with pneumonia and should be coded additionally (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would miss the non-integral symptom that should be coded
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Failing to code non-integral symptoms that are present

warnings: Must code non-integral symptoms when present (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
best_practices: Evaluate each symptom for its relationship to the primary disease (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
Code all non-integral symptoms that are documented (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
common_mistakes: Failing to code unrelated symptoms (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
Assuming all symptoms are integral to the primary disease (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
tips: Consider whether the symptom would be expected with the primary disease (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
When in doubt, code the additional symptom (Evidence: pg no: 13, L45-L46)
implementation_notes: Requires clinical judgment to determine symptom relationships
clinical_context: Ensures complete documentation of patient's condition
Important for quality measures and severity of illness
